subject: Re: Keyman 6.0 layout
msgSnippet: Һýëîó, ²ңãë³ø ³í Ñ³ð³ë³ê ëүêñ êóàéò íàéñ. There (if your computer displays it) is a short example of my scheme for writing
messageBody:
ҺЩКНС, ╡ңЦКЁЬ ЁМ яЁПЁКЁЙ КүЙЯ ЙСЮИР МЮИЯ.
There (if your computer displays it) is a short example of my scheme
for writing English in Cyrillic. I had to modify some of the letter
sounds to make them fit for English and added several non-Russian
letters. using "i" for an "it" vowel conforms better to the original
Greek usage. Unfortunately "awe" and "on" are both represented
with "o".
Plus, unless you are on a serious mission to give yourself CTS,
Quickscript is a much better alterative.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...>
wrote:
>
> teraiten skrev:
>
> > This keyboard interprets combinations of letters and
> > converts these to the appropriate Quickscript characters.
> > The transcription scheme is NewRomaji. I can't find any
> > sources online about NewRomaji, it's from something I
> > printed out years ago. I made a few minor changes to the
> > "official" NewRomaji scheme. It'll also automatically
> > convert n to N when followed by a g or k.
>
> Wouldn't it be possible to set things up so that <ng> prints
> QS letter #21 but <ngg> prints #21 + #6? That's how
> Indonesian orthography distinguishes these two, and it's
> quite intuitive once you get used to it.
>
> FWIW: 20+ years ago I toyed around with writing the three
> sounds that don't have their own single letters in Swedish
> orthography so that tj > c, sj > x and ng > q (and of course
> replacing the present uses of c and x with s/k and ks! :-).
> For some reason the tj > c and sj > x remappings felt
> totally natural, while ng > q never really felt right. I can
> get used to q for various back stops and fricatives, but not
> for a nasal for some reason.
>
> Otherwise the idea of applying Japanese Romaji to English is
> as good as any. I feel that the Cyrillizations of English
> loanwords 'make sense' (although one would like to design
> some letters for the 'as' and 'us' vowels). I wonder how I
> would react to a whole page of Cyrillic English -- or its
> retransliteration according to the usual way Russian is
> rendered in the English alphabet.
>
> /BP 8^)
> --
> B.Philip Jonsson mailto:melrochX@... (delete X)
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> "Truth, Sir, is a cow which will give [skeptics] no more milk,
> and so they are gone to milk the bull."
> -- Sam. Johnson (no rel. ;)
>
